abstract.p: Producer Thomas A DeLong letter on Robert Simonson's July 30 article lauds Westport Country Playhouse as mecca for apprentices and interns (S)

block.p: Besides offering a stage for new theatrical material and, in the process, boosting the careers of such actors as Jane Wyatt, E. G. Marshall, Kitty Carlisle Hart and Cloris Leachman, the Westport Country Playhouse has been a mecca for apprentices and interns [''A Summer Veteran Gets New Life'' by Robert Simonson, July 30].

Besides offering a stage for new theatrical material and, in the process, boosting the careers of such actors as Jane Wyatt, E. G. Marshall, Kitty Carlisle Hart and Cloris Leachman, the Westport Country Playhouse has been a mecca for apprentices and interns [''A Summer Veteran Gets New Life'' by Robert Simonson, July 30].

In years past, a dozen or so novices eager for practical stage experience headed there every summer. Many made the grade. The Playhouse handyman Zachary Scott went on to acting on Broadway and in films in the early 1940's. The composer-lyricist Stephen Sondheim honed his musical proficiency there, as did the conductor Jonathan Sheffer and the composer-educator Mary Rodgers. Christina Crawford, the actress and author of ''Mommie Dearest,'' called Westport ''a jewel among summer stock theaters.'' And the future talk-show host Sally Jessy Raphael did everything from painting sets to driving actors around.
The writer is the producer of ''Stage Presence: An Exhibit Celebrating 70 Years of the Westport Country Playhouse'' at the Westport Historical Society.
